title: Friday, 3rd March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Friday

PM11:01am

Guess you can have a pick of Sir Martin

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Or is he Lord now?

PM11:01am

And if not, why not

PM11:01am

11:01 am
PM11:01am

WPP taken a battering this morning

PM11:02am

Which we can come to

PM11:02am

But more broadly

11:02 am
PM11:02am

I'm struck by the amount of volatility we seen on regular news announcements

PM11:02am

There's some sort of disconnect that has crept up on us

PM11:03am

Is this analysts being slow witted?

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Is it regulation choking off the supply of intel

PM11:03am

?

PM11:03am

It's not just on the downside

11:03 am
PM11:03am

And it's not just smaller stocks

PM11:03am

WPP is not small

PM11:04am

But it's routine now to see moves of 5/6/8 % or more

11:03 am
BE11:04am

Has it really snuck up on us? I've been banging for ages on about the restrictions put on investor relations departments giving any kind of guidance and how it leads to a messier consensus.

PM11:04am

Yeah, this is true

PM11:04am

DutchBrat -- mentions volumes as well

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Which is also a factor

PM11:05am

And as Golly notes, we can also blame the machines

BE11:05am

Unconvinced by the volumes argument. Turnover looks okay to me, though is distributed a bit more.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

And blaming machines is just tedious. You may as well say "there be dragons".

PM11:06am

Well we've got to blame someone or something

PM11:06am

Happy to settle with IR for now

11:06 am
BE11:06am

I'm sticking with the fear of giving guidance theme.

BE11:06am

First we saw it with the oil companies, which are an absolute nightmare to forecast. They started beating and missing by 50% or so each quarter.

BE11:06am

Now we're seeing it deeper, in stuff like WPP.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

hmm

BE11:07am

We're also seeing the effects in things like Inmarsat, which was hammered last month with the FD tried to add some context to the 2017 consensus.

BE11:08am

It's the silencing of grey-market guidance, thank you FCA. And into that vacuum fear rushes.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Let's head into WPP tho.

PM11:08am

Yeah

PM11:08am

I'm obviously a bit slow

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But I can't see what would cause a 7% hit to the market price

BE11:09am

Guidance is poor.

BE11:09am

2% organic, rather than the 3% expected by the consensus.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Numbers here bntw http://www.investe...1703030700084151Y/

BE11:10am

Perhaps, if Sir Martin had said during one of his numerous conference appearances that organic growth expectations were looking a wee bit toppy, it wouldn't have been such a surprise.

BE11:10am

But that returns us to our first point.

11:10 am
PM11:11am

Indeed it does

BE11:11am

Let's get Morgan Stanley to summarise the numbers.

BE11:11am

The numbers were in line but the outlook is disappointing with a slow January for organic net sales growth (+1.2%) vs MSe at 3.25% and guidance of 2% points net sales growth in FY 17 (most were looking for 3% again). Despite WPP still looking for another 30bps improvement in margins in 2017 consensus eps forecasts are likely to slip in 2017 to c125p ( css 130p, MSe 134p) WPP has produced a small beat with PBIT of £2160m (MSe £2147m), eps of 113.2p (MSe 112.7p) and a 27% increase in the dividend to 56.6p (MSe 56p).

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Organic net sales growth was 3.1% as expected implying 2.1% growth in Q4 (Q1 was 3.2%, Q2 4.4%, Q3 2.8%) against a tough comp. On a two year basis the growth rates are 5.7% in Q1, 6.5% in Q2, 6.1% in Q3 and 7% in Q4, meaning Q4 was actually the fastest growth quarter of the year on this basis.

BE11:11am

WPP says that January net sales growth is just 1.2% (MSe 3.25%). January 2016 is not a particularly tough comp at +2.3% in 2016. 2017 budget is behind expectations: WPP says that it has been set conservatively but 'Given continued tepid economic growth and recent weaker comparative net new business trends, the budgets for 2017, on a like-for-like basis, have been set conservatively at around 2% for both revenue and net sales, but with a headline operating margin target improvement on net sales of 0.3 margin points, in constant currency.'

BE11:11am

The 2% growth is the disappointment – most commentators had been looking for 3% growth organically. 2% organic net sales growth would put WPP at the low end of the expected growth of the agencies group.
WPP puts it down to a tepid economic environment and lower new business wins. WPP lost AT&T at the end of 2016 and VW from the start of 2017. This may be impacting WPP’s revenue thinking. Net new business was £4.36bn in 2016 (2017 was £5.56bn).

11:11 am
BE11:12am

US net sales growth at just 0.5% in Q4 was disappointing. WPP sees signs of Brexit slowdown in UK with net sales declining 0.6% in Q4. Europe was at +2.7% in Q4 and ROW relatively strong at 4.8%. Given the higher starting point (the 2016 margin was up 50bps instead of the expected 40bps) and the expectation of another 30bps margin improvement in 2017, the impact on EBITA is limited but higher interest and tax means that eps forecasts are likely to fall to c125p-128p (css 130p, MSe 134p).
Average net debt is surprisingly high at £4.34bn (1.8x Net Debt/EBITDA). Consensus was on £3.7bn and MSe on £3.5bn. The difference is equivalent to c3% of WPP market cap. The increase is due to £466m of translation differences (sterling weakness), £144m of debt acquired from STW and £270m of working capital movements and non-trade provisions. This trend has continued in the first seven weeks of 2017, with average net debt of £4.2bn, compared with £3.4bn in the same period in 2016, an increase of £787 million.

BE11:12am

No restructuring charge: A better piece of news is that there no restructuring charge. In the last two years WPP has made restructuring charges at this time of year (£106m related to severance at Kantar at the FY15 FY stage and £128m in 2014 for European restructuring). Back in December WPP had said that it expected a similar year in 2017 to 2016 ( ie c3% net sales growth) and a margin target of 30bps pre currency.

BE11:12am

And Barclays, just the conclusion, and much shorter.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The key question for the meeting becomes how conservative is this 2.0% budget. Adding WPP historical trading seasonality means the shares are likely to pause for breath but we would argue that WPP remains extremely cheap for the growth delivered (14.3x 2017E P/E, a 5% discount to the FTSE100; 10% EPS growth through a whole cycle). WPP is our Top Pick. We are Overweight with a 2,200p target price.

PM11:13am

Top pick eh?

BE11:13am

WPP's a consensus buy I think.

11:14 am
undefined
BE11:14am

Right, to tackle a few things on the other side of the page ............

BE11:15am

Bloody Genfit.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

French thing?

BE11:15am

Yep. Kepler Cheuvreux's events desk shoved out a bit of M&A tin rattling halfway through yesterday

BE11:16am

Saying it "may have already engaged in early talks" with potential buyers

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Isnt this a re-heat of the Novartis story?

BE11:16am

Yes! It is! Names Novartis , Sanofi and Shire as possible buyers.

BE11:17am

And puts a E65 target to the rumour.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Kepler's been pushing Genfit as an M&A target forever.

PM11:17am

Streetinsider also pushing the story -- without a price

PM11:17am

https://www.street...urce/12620013.html

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Yep, that came slightly later.

PM11:18am

ok

BE11:19am

This is a constant theme, to which we can add very little. Here's Oppenheimer on why Novartis kinda makes sense.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

As a potential competitor to ICPT, Genfit's dual PPAR alpha/delta agonist (elafibranor) is in Ph3 studies for NASH. There has been increased speculation about potential deals in the NASH space since AGN announced plans to acquire Tobira in Aug. 2016.

BE11:20am

Meanwhile, as for Aberdeen ....

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 282.30, down 2 (-0.70%), High: 286.30, Low: 281.40, Volume: 1.26m
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Every punter's gone into this one over the past week or so. Hence the increased rumoutrage reaching the papers.

BE11:21am

Standard yesterday. Telegraph and ... us .... the day before.

BE11:21am

We don't know what the story is. We don't know if there's a story.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We know that Gilbert would quite like a US distribution business and thinks the Henderson-Janus tie-up was clever and sensible.

PM11:22am

The Credit Suisse angle caused quite a rumpus for one of our colleagues a while back, of course

PM11:22am

Martin Arnold

11:22 am
PM11:22am

I can't find the piece with FT search

BE11:23am

Hm. Suffice to say, the Credit Suisse-Aberdeen link is one that comes up perpetually, for various reasons.

BE11:24am

And hasn't been true to the point of requiring an announcement so far.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Beyond that, if there is something specific happening with Aberdeen we don't know about it. Sorry. Good luck, punters.

undefined
PM11:25am

Allied Minds also mentioned on the right

11:25 am
PM11:25am

There's some sort of rule change to the way Mid 250 companies are weighted -- or this might just be AM related

PM11:25am

But the theory is that index-huggers need to buy more of the thing

Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 418.76, up 10.76 (+2.64%), High: 426.90, Low: 396.80, Volume: 211.44k
11:25 am
PM11:26am

Know nothing beyond that

BE11:26am

Nearly six times the time-of-day volume of Allied traded when I last checked!

BE11:26am

Or, 150,000 shares.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

It's not exactly liquid.

undefined
BE11:26am

So, to warnings.

11:26 am
Berendsen PLC (BRSN:LSE): Last: 779.00, down 150.5 (-16.19%), High: 826.00, Low: 751.50, Volume: 3.19m
PM11:27am

Dirty laundry

PM11:27am

http://www.investe...1703030700074118Y/

11:27 am
BE11:27am

2016 is in line with lowered expectations. 2017 isn't.

BE11:27am

"legacy UK operations" still the issue.

BE11:28am

Who was arguing the other week that the UK business was now in Berendsen's valuation at zero?

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Looks like shareholders disagree.

BE11:28am

Any turnaround will be second-half weighted

BE11:29am

And expect EBIT of £150m, 12% below consensus.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Barclays incoming.

BE11:29am

BRSN has reported FY16 operating profit of £161m, +5% yoy on a reported basis, -4% on a constant currency basis, and in-line with guidance of c£160m provided in last October’s trading update; adj EPS +4% and DPS +5%. More interestingly, guidance has now been issued for FY17 with management indicating an operating profit of £150m with a higher than usual 2H weighting – this guidance is 10% below our current FY17 operating profit forecast for FY17 of £167m (we are slightly below Thomson Reuters consensus of £169m) – with an FX benefit of c£6-8m in FY17, this implies underlying operating profit decline yoy of 11% in FY17 which is attributed to the UK issues first outlined in October 2016. Turning to cash, free cash flow fell from £102m to £47m, with FCF conversion of 44%, well below management’s target of 75-90% (and we note the metric of free cash conversion appears to have disappeared from guidance/key metrics); net debt increased £59m with £44m of this from FX and net debt/EBITDA at y/e was 1.0x. Looking forward, FCF is likely to remain subdued with today’s statement outlining plans to spend a total of £450m over the next three years on plant & machinery with £200m in the UK; c1/3 of the total is maintenance with the remainder being invested in further plant conversions and new build plants at a targeted 15% pre-tax return – for context, in the last 5 years, average spend on plant & machinery has been £33m (£47m in FY16). Prior to any potential forecast adjustments BRSN is trading on a FY17 PE of 14.2x.

BE11:31am

And ..... RBC. Was RBC pushing earlier on the UK being written off theory? I think they were.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

FY results are broadly in line with expectations (EBITA £161m vs Oct guidance of £160m), although underlying growth was weaker than expected. However,
2017 guidance is for a 40/60 H1/H2 weighting and EBITA of £150m (7% below our forecast of £162m) – reflecting primarily further costs and issues in the UK.
Management has a turnaround plan for the UK and expects to invest £450m in plant and machinery over the next 3 years of which £150m is maintenance capex
– management expects a 15% pretax return on this investment. This is around £100m pa higher than our forecasts. It is clearly disappointing that numbers
come down again but it is good news that an improvement plan is now in place, although clearly there are execution risks and the investment involved will
severely impact FCF generation in the short-term. When we upgraded the stock recently, we said that at below 870p, the UK is in the share price for nothing –
this remains the case, although recovery is clearly going to take time and H1 numbers are not going to be pretty.

undefined
PM11:32am

Just looking at these flow stats

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Roar: Fed rhetoric endorsing March hike + Trump speech = largest daily inflow (March 1st) to the SPY ETF since Dec'14 ($8bn)

PM11:32am

Snap from Merrill

PM11:33am

Inflows to "inflation assets"...materials, infrastructure, commodities; Treasuries see largest outflows in 10 weeks ($1.4bn)

11:32 am
PM11:33am

I find it quite extraordinary

PM11:33am

The bullishness on Wall St

PM11:33am

Even if the Dow was off yesterday

11:33 am
PM11:33am

We havent mentioned Snap

BE11:33am

Hm.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Marktes Live

11:33 am
PM11:34am

Where did it settle

PM11:34am

24.71

PM11:34am

Against the $17 sale price

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Hm.

PM11:34am

What's that? 30 times revenues i think

PM11:34am

To play with funny faces

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Yeah, it's a silly valuation. Absurd. Crazy. Unjustifiable. This. Is. Nuts.

BE11:35am

Pivotal, whose figures we quoted yesterday, have a sell initiation out that I'll come to in a moment.

BE11:36am

It makes all the sensible arguments about slices of the advertising market and revenue generation based on installed users and all that.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

But I do suspect we're missing the wider context of Snap.

PM11:36am

Go on

BE11:36am

We're viewing it as an IPO, when it's not really. At least not in the form we're used to.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

It has more in common with a nationalisation than a standard float.

PM11:37am

Omg smile??

BE11:37am

Which is a logical consequence of the fact that the equity market is now mostly a mechanism for early investors to take money out, not for businesses to raise cash.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

The way I see it, it would've only been mildly surprising if Snap engineered an exit by selling to Facebook for $20bn or whatever.

BE11:38am

Which would likely to have involved Zuck pledging management independence and stuff.

PM11:38am

Hmm -- public markets no longer for capital formation

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Just price discovery

PM11:38am

And even that is gamed by the banks

BE11:38am

Yep.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Thing is, Facebook can't buy Snap. Facebook doesn't want to draw the attention of the antitrusters, and owning all of the top whatever messaging clients would do that.

PM11:39am

Sure would

BE11:40am

There aren't many companies left of a scale that could buy Snap.

11:39 am
PM11:40am

(Flaneur -- certainly is. All modern ills can be traced to QE, no?)

BE11:40am

So instead it's been sold to investors at an M&A multiple. And those investors have pledged management independence and stuff

BE11:40am

It's a crowdfunded acquisition, not an IPO.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Hence no votes, etc

PM11:40am

hehehe

PM11:40am

This is a good way of looking at the thing.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Almost normalises it

PM11:41am

Crowdfunded acquisition

BE11:41am

It's investors generating their own tension in an M&A market that has very few buyers left who are able to pay puffy dot-comedy multiples.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

That's why it's a nationalisation. It's the Street protecting itself.

BE11:42am

It's reinventing the equity market as a friendlier mechanism for PE and venture fund exits, by removing most of the definition of what we used to call shares.

PM11:42am

hehehe

11:43 am
BE11:43am

And it's keeping the plates spinning with relation to the crazy valuations they've put on all the other dot-comedy 2.0 stuff.

BE11:44am

Imagine if Snap had tanked? What then? Sending it out the trap at 10 times revenue or whatever is an exercise in communal preservation. It's not a float.

BE11:44am

Anyway. Want this Pivotal note to tell you it's expensive?

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Yes please!

BE11:44am

They're conclusion is that it's expensive.

BE11:44am

Snap is a promising early stage company with significant opportunity ahead of itself. Unfortunately, it is significantly overvalued given the likely scale of its long-term opportunity and the risks associated with executing against that opportunity. Significant ongoing dilution from share-based compensation will likely represent an additional negative consideration for the stock. We value Snap at $10 per share on a YE2017 basis. As the stock priced well above this level in its IPO, we rate its shares Sell.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Snap presents investors with the opportunity to invest in the company behind an innovative, large-scale, and distinctively young-skewing platform which is establishing itself as a magnet for business unit talent and content partners alike. Snap also offers investors a share of the significant economic potential that should follow from Snap’s ongoing business expansion.

BE11:45am

At the same time, there are significant risks offsetting these opportunities. Investors in
Snap will be exposed to an upstart facing aggressive competition from much larger
companies, with a core user base that is not growing by much and which is only relatively elusive. It has a promising and innovative advertising offering, but so far it is still mostly unproven and difficult to quantify its ultimate scale. Investors will also be
exposed to what appears to be a sub-optimal corporate structure operated by a senior management team lacking experience transforming a successful new product into a
successful company. High expenses and cash costs to run the company are negative as well. And then there are other negatives for shareholders given the degree to which they will be diluted through aggressive share issuances to employees and through the lack of voting rights that they will possess.

BE11:45am

While we consider ourselves cautious optimists on the business itself, our model feels potentially “stretched” in even getting to $10 per share, or a $16bn valuation on a YE2017 basis. As the stock priced well above this level in its IPO, we rate its shares Sell.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Yeah probably. $10, or $1, or $100. Doesn't really matter. W'evs.

PM11:46am

That's a pretty level headed read

BE11:46am

(@Shortfuse: Brian Wieser of Pivotal.)

11:46 am
BE11:47am

It might do $6.7 billion of revenue by 2023, as Pivotal forecasts with plenty of very good working, or it might not.

BE11:48am

But investing on 2023 revenue for a company that's only existed since 2011 seems ........... well, it's not an argument about numbers, is it?

BE11:48am

It's an existential argument. Snap is an existential. Think of that next time you set the face filter to puke rainbows.

11:48 am
undefined
PM11:48am

While we are in the space

PM11:49am

How's Twitter doing these days?

11:48 am
PM11:49am

hmm

PM11:49am

$15.80

PM11:49am

ie not well

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Pretty steady decay from that initial spike three years ago

PM11:49am

Time flies eh

BE11:49am

We were massive sellers on the debut day, of course.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

https://ftalphavil...live/2013-11-07-2/

PM11:50am

We were!

PM11:50am

Painful for a period

11:50 am
undefined
PM11:50am

What else to go through?

BE11:51am

Um ........ not much.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Sellside wise we have Barclays pushing WH Smith.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,746, up 48 (+2.83%), High: 1,810, Low: 1,735, Volume: 444.81k
BE11:51am

With one of the great sellside opening sentences of our time.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

There is a Twitter handle called @WHS_Carpet, which includes pictures of poorly repaired carpets and badly stocked shelves in WH Smith shops. We see this criticism as similar to that of many investors who assume the shares will collapse when the high street ‘goes wrong’.

BE11:51am

Our analysis indicates that stable cash generation from High Street is sustainable, driven by gross margin gains, but also through other areas such as rent deflation, and growth in funkypigeon.com.

BE11:52am

WH Smith Carpets is very good: https://twitter.com/WHS_Carpet

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Though alone it's not a reason to buy Twitter. To be clear.

BE11:52am

Back to Barclays.

BE11:52am

In addition, we believe that the reliance on High Street will continue to fall as Travel grows. We expect over £100m of International revenue in FY17E (from just c£10m in FY11), driving c£9m of EBIT, 6% of group profit. We believe that EBIT from International could double again in 4 years, helped by contract wins and gradual margin improvements after pre-opening costs fall. The recent contract win of 10 stores at Changhi Airport in Singapore (the 16th busiest airport in the world) is another example illustrating that WH Smith is a force to be reckoned with in global travel retail. Given the current low single digit market share, International Travel could potentially surpass EBIT from UK Travel in the very long term. We upgrade our rating to OW from EW and raise our PT to £19.90. We believe a re-rating is warranted given: i) falling dependency on High Street (now just 40% of EBIT, and 32% of our EV), ii) rising ROCE, iii) potential market share growth in International for at least a decade, and iv) the FY17 FCF yield of 7% is very attractive vs our coverage universe.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Upside case of £22.40, 32% upside potential – the sky is the limit for International:
Landlords receiving turnover based rents are focused on appointing the best operators, and WH Smith’s track record of improving spending per passenger is gaining traction. This can be seen given contract wins from AENA (in Alicante), hubs in the Middle East and Australia, along with Changhi. Our upside case, which assumes more optimistic margin assumptions for International, implies £406m of value, 15% of the EV.
Downside case: £12.13, 28% downside risk: We believe that High Street EBIT will edge higher, but many investors express significant caution on this division. Lowering our EV/EBIT for Travel to 12x along with a more cautious EV/EBIT of 5x for High Street, drives our downside case of £12.13. If we simply apply no value to high street, and retain an EV/EBIT of 16x for Travel, our fair value would be £13.26, 22% downside.

BE11:53am

............ Which brings us back to another favourite theme.

BE11:53am

WH Smith’s UK Travel does a margin of 16.2%!

11:53 am
BE11:53am

WH Smith UK High Street does a margin of 9%.

BE11:53am

They're the same damn shops.

BE11:54am

They sell the same damn stuff to the same damn people.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

But one location is monopolistic and the other isnt

BE11:54am

Yes. In what world do we not consider this kind of margin differential exploiting a monopoly?

BE11:55am

Irrelevant to whether the monopoly is natural.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

(@doeswalk: are "captive passengers" special people who never ever leave train stations? Like morlocks?)

BE11:56am

It's an argument we've done with SSP for ages, and you don't need me to remind you how comfy the relationship is between SSP and WH Smith.

BE11:58am

It makes me nervous when companies share managements and the like given the -- entirely theoretical! to be clear! -- potential for collusion with regards pitch bidding in public spaces.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Anyway. that's that. Buy WH Smith as it rolls out its model of charging airport customers £2.50 for a bottle of Evian internationally.

PM11:58am

(wayneJ -- you need to look at CPM rates. FT 50-100 times social platform inventory. But we only have so many readers...)

BE11:58am

................. Or don't. Not fussed.

11:58 am
undefined
PM11:59am

Look at the time

PM11:59am

Just mention Rocket in passing

11:59 am
PM11:59am

Down 4%

PM11:59am

17.34

PM11:59am

Slow decay continues

11:59 am
PM11:59am

But what gets me -- it's still doing start up financing in this parallel fun it has

PM12:00pm

OpenRent, one of a number of online letting agents (or realtor, as it might be described in the U.S.), has picked up £4.4 million in backing from Rocket Internet’s venture arm Global Founders Capital.

The London-based company’s last funding round was a “multi-million pound” ‘equity for media’ deal with Northern & Shell Ventures, part of the independently-owned UK media group which operates Express Newspapers, The Health Lottery and OK! magazine (and, until very recently, TV station Channel 5).

PM12:00pm

Very odd

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

https://techcrunch...ket-internets-gfc/

undefined
PM12:00pm

Ok, we are done

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:01pm

And cheers for joining us on the right

PM12:01pm

hang on...

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Wait!

BE12:01pm

*U.K. GOVERNMENT ‘MINDED’ TO INVESTIGATE FOX-SKY DEAL

PM12:01pm

ooh

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Actually, that's not interesting is it?

BE12:01pm

Of course it'll investigate it.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 999.00, up 0.5 (+0.05%), High: 1,002, Low: 997.50, Volume: 1.05m
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

(Bloomberg) -- “I am minded to issue a European Intervention Notice on the basis that I have concerns that there may be public interest considerations - as set out in the Enterprise Act 2002 - that are relevant to this proposed merger that warrant further investigation,” Culture, Media and Sport secretary Karen Bradley says in statement Friday.
“To be clear - I have not taken a final decision on intervention at this stage”: Bradley
“I am inviting written representations from the parties and will aim to come to a final decision on whether to intervene in the merger within ten working days of today’s notification”: Bradley

BE12:02pm

Sorry -- false alarm. That's just kinda dull. Ignore me, close it up.

PM12:02pm

Nah, good to check

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

We're off

PM12:03pm

Bye

PM11:33am

Quite exciting to watch yesterday
